boat.name: Dusmarie
boat.full_description:
'Dusmarie', originally called 'Daisy', was built in 1884 as an oyster smack by Aldous of Brightlingsea. She worked under sail, fishing no. CK12, until 1932 when she was sold, converted to a yacht, and renamed. Under her owner, Commander Douglas Herbert Dixon, she was sailed to the Baltic and remained there for the duration of the Second World War.

Rescued in 1945, she was re-built and converted to a yawl in 1947. She was also fitted with an engine, in 1952 a Stuart Turner 8hp and a single cylinder Saab 10hp in 1972.

She took part in several Tall Ships Races in the 1970s, often with an all female crew, skippered by Astrid Llewellyn (Douglas Dixon's daughter).
boat.short_description: 'Dusmarie' is an oyster smack, built in Brightlingsea 1884 by Aldous & Sons. She was originally called 'Daisy' fishing no. CK12.

for_sales.sales_text:
"Dusmarie" is an oyster smack, built in Brightlingsea 1884 by Aldous & Sons. She was originally called "Daisy". Bought by Douglas and Mary Dixon from Zebedee Milgate in 1932, she was converted to a sailing cruiser, 1933, and re-named "Dusmarie". She is much travelled (Baltic, North Sea, Mediterranean and many Tall Ships races) skippered by Astrid Dixon, often with an all-female crew. She remained in the Dixon family until 1994, and was sold to the current owner in 2001.

She is on the National Register of Historic Vessels and in 2006 was judged number 23 of the 250 British Classics selected by Classic Boat Magazine.

The current owner, reluctantly and because of advancing years and grandchildren, is seeking the next steward to sail and enjoy this unique piece of East Coast maritime history.
